Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, half-listening as my stepdad suggested a family hike for the weekend. My stepbrother’s eyes lit up, and my mom smiled, nudging me to join in the excitement. “It’ll be fun, right?” she said, and I nodded, feeling the weight of their expectation. They wanted me to be part of the family, to show I cared about these new bonds we were building. But in my pocket, my phone buzzed—a reminder from my mentor about the code sample I needed to finish before our next meeting. The assignment was tough, and I knew I’d need most of the weekend to get it right. My mentor always said, “Show me you’re committed,” and I wanted to prove I was serious about learning. As my family looked at me, waiting for my answer, I felt torn. If I said yes to the hike, I’d disappoint my mentor and risk falling behind. If I said no, I’d let down my family, who just wanted me to belong. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out what to do, caught between two worlds that both mattered to me.
